section.title: Solor definitional knowledge
section.para: In order to represent the various domains of healthcare, Solor "stands on the shoulder of giants" by building on existing content from SNOMED, LOINC, and RxNorm. Purpose of this section is to discuss the categories within Solor where concepts resides, as well as the relationships used to define the concepts. Ultimately, the goal of this representation of concepts and its relationships would support the description logic component of Solor.

section.title: Top Level Categories
section.para: In SNOMED, various hierarchies (i.e. Procedures, Clinical Findings, etc) are used to store and maintain various concepts. These hierarchies are typically modeled such that higher level concepts (i.e. Disorder of endocrine system) are more generic than lower level concepts, which are more granular (i.e. Type 1 diabetes mellitus). Through series of isA relationships, which will be explained in the next section, one could traverse down the hierarchy from a top level generic concept to a very specific concept. In an attempt to gather 'like' concepts, Solor created top level categories or concepts to 'house' concepts that belong to those categories. This section will describe the intent and purpose of these categories.

section.title: Body Structure
section.para: Contains both normal and abnormal anatomical structures.

section.title: Environment or geographical location
section.para: Contains both types of environments and named locations such as countries.

section.title: Event
section.para: Events are different from procedures in that they are occurrences that impact health or health care.

section.title: Medication
section.para: This hierarchy is comparable to the Pharmaceutical / biologic product in SNOMED CT and used to represent drug products.

section.title: Object
section.para: Natural and man-made objects encountered in the healthcare environment.

section.title: Organism
section.para: An individual entity that exhibits the properties of life.

section.title: Phenomenon
section.para: This Hierarchy contains both Observable Entities, Clinical Findings, and Disorders.

section.title: Procedure
section.para: Procedures are actions performed in the provision of health care.

section.title: Qualifier value
section.para: Miscellaneous concepts used to represent the values for definitional relationships in SNOMED CT.

section.title: Record artifact
section.para: The Record artifact hierarchy is used to represent the names of a clinical document or parts of a clinical document.

section.title: Situation with explicit context
section.para: Clinical findings or Procedures that have contextual information applied to them. This can include concepts like Family history, Procedures performed in the past or planned in the future.

section.title: SNOMED CT Model Component
section.para: Concepts and attributes used to create and organize SNOMED CT.

section.title: Social context
section.para: Social conditions and circumstances, for example ethnic groups, life styles, occupations, and religions.

section.title: Special concept
section.para: Inactive and navigational concepts from SNOMED CT.

section.title: Specimen
section.para: Material collected for examination or analysis. Usually from a patient but can also be obtained from other sources, for example a catheter or the environment.

section.title: Stages and scales
section.para: SNOMED CT concepts used to represent stages, grades and scales.

section.title: Substance
section.para: Physical matter from which something is made or which has discrete existence. This hierarchy includes allergens, agents, substances, and materials used to define Medications, Phenomenon, and Procedures.

section.title: Relationship Types
section.para: As alluded in earlier sections, each concept with a name by itself does not provide any additional knowledge to reason. If "Disorder of endocrine system" concept is placed into a bucket of like concepts, such as "Type 1 diabetes mellitus", without any formal definition, one could not possibly deduce that "Type 1 diabetes mellitus" is a type of endocrine system disorder. Therefore, a series of relationships must be used to properly define the concept so that the concept could contain additional knowledge for reasoning to occur. With the simple example of diabetes, it may seem that one could simply create a "Is A" relationship to relate "Disorder of endocrine system" and "Type 1 diabetes mellitus". Although it may connect these two concepts, there needs to be additional relationship types to further define each concept to provide more context and knowledge such that a concept is further defined and could provide additional knowledge. This section describes the relationship types of Solor and provides example of its usage.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Is a Relationships are used to represent a hierarchical parent/child relationship between two concepts.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

Ordinal or quantitative value (qualifier value) OR

section.title: Associated with
section.para: The Associated with attribute is used to define Phenomenon to specify an association between two concepts that doesn't explicitly state a causal relationship.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Insert definition here.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Anemia associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (disorder) has an Associated with of Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (disorder)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

section.title: Associated With Subtype Roles
section.para: Associated With has three Subtype Attributes: Causative agent, Due to, and Temporally related to.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para:
The term disease causative agent usually refers to the biological pathogen that causes a disease, such as a virus, parasite, fungus, or bacterium, or can refer to a toxin or toxic chemical that causes illness. Welding fume as a causative agent.
Welding of stainless steel is a well recognised cause of occupational asthma, the chrome in the fume has been shown to be the cause in some challenge tests. Non-stainless steel welding is more problematic as specific causative agents have not been demonstrated, but nevertheless occupational asthma occurs. Probably the best evidence comes from longitudinal studies of apprentice welders.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Priapism caused by drug (disorder) has an Causative agent of Drug or medicament (substance)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Due to is used to relate a Phenomenon directly with its cause.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Epilepsy due to cerebrovascular accident (disorder) has a Due to relationship of Cerebrovascular accident (disorder)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Temporally related to is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to specify the clinical entity occuring either before, during or after a phenomenon

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: This attribute is currently not used to define a concept in SNOMED CT. However the subtype attributes are used.

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

section.title: Temporally related to Subtype Roles
section.para: Temporally related to has two subtype attributes, Before and During AND/OR after.

row.entry: Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Donor for medical or surgical procedure (social concept) OR
Administration of substance via specific route
Ordinal or quantitative value (qualifier value) OR

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: This attribute describes the route used to access the site of a procedure and used to distinguish open, closed or percutaneous procedures.

formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

section.title: All or part of Subtype Roles
section.para: All or part of currently has one subtype role, Part of.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Insert definition here.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

section.title: Part of Subtype Roles
section.para: Part of has four subtype roles that can be further used to define Body structures.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Insert definition here.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Insert definition here.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Laterality is an attribute used to represent the side of the body to which the body structure belongs. It is only used for body structures that are symmetric to both sides of the body and is not used to represent sidedness.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Structure of right knee region (body structure) has a Laterality of Right (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Structure of right side of heart (body structure) should not have a Laterality since it describes a side of the heart and not a right heart.

section.title: Situation with explicit context Relationship Types

table.title: Situation with explicit context Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Links the Situation with explicit context concept to the related Phenomenon or Event

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Family history: Diabetes mellitus (situation) has an Associated finding of Diabetes mellitus (disorder)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Links the Situation with explicit context concept to the related Procedure

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: 183985008 |Renal transplant planned (situation)| has an Associated procedure of Transplant of kidney (procedure)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Finding context is used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy to represent whether a Phenomenon or Event is known or unknown.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Chvostek sign positive (situation) has a Finding context of Known present (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Procedure context is used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy to represent the status of a Procedure

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Hemodialysis procedure done (situation) has a Procedure context of Done (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Subject relationship context is used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy to represent the relationship of the finding or procedure to the subject of record. This can be the subject of record or someone else.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: History of arthritis (situation) has a Subject relationship context of Subject of record (person). Family history: Alzheimer's disease (situation) has a Subject relationship context of Person in family of subject (person)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: This attribute represents the time of a procedure or finding when used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Hip replacement planned (situation) has a Temporal context of Current or specified time (qualifier value). The concept History of malignant neoplasm (situation) has a Temporal context of In the past (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

table.title: Substance Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Has disposition attribute relates a Substance with the behavior that the substance will exhibit or participate in.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Estradiol (substance) has a Has disposition of Estrogen (disposition)

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

table.title: Specimen Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

row.entry: Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen procedure is used in the Specimen hierarchy to represent the procedure perfomed to obtain the specimen.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Specimen from eye obtained by fine needle aspiration biopsy (specimen) has a Specimen procedure of Fine needle aspiration biopsy of eye (procedure).

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen source identity is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the person, group or location from which a specimen was collected.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Environmental swab (specimen) has a Specimen source identity of Environment (environment).

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen source morphology is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the morphologic abnormality from which the specimen was obtained.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Swab from abscess of brain (specimen) has a Specimen source morphology of Abscess (morphologic abnormality).

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen source topography is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the body structure from which the specimen was obtained.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Excised breast ectopic tissue sample (specimen) has a Specimen source topography of Breast structure (body structure).

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen substance is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the type of substance a specimen is comprised.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example of correct use
formalpara.para: Arterial blood specimen (specimen) has a Specimen substance of Arterial blood (substance).

formalpara.title: Example of incorrect use
formalpara.para: Give an example of incorrect use here.
